private_information: I can manipulate only vowel-labeled blocks: A, E, I, O, U.
I can only pick up or place a block if it is the top block of a stack.
I can move only one block at a time.
vowel_agent.goal: Contribute to achieving the target stacking order by moving vowel blocks subject to my constraints.

private_information: I can manipulate only consonant-labeled blocks: B, C, D, F, G, H, J and others.
I can only pick up or place a block if it is the top block of a stack.
I can move only one block at a time.
consonant_agent.goal: Contribute to achieving the target stacking order by moving consonant blocks subject to my constraints.

orchestrator.goal: Integrate the agents' analyses and produce a complete PDDL domain and problem file suitable for the FastDownwards solver that achieves the global stacking goal.

public_information: There are ten uniquely labelled blocks: G, I, D, F, C, B, H, A, J, E.
Only the block at the top of a stack can be moved, and only one block can be moved at a time.
Initially: G is on the table.
Initially: I is on the table.
Initially: D is on the table.
Initially: F is on top of G.
Initially: C is on top of I.
Initially: B is on top of C.
Initially: H is on top of D.
Initially: A is on top of F.
Initially: J is on top of A.
Initially: E is on top of H.
The goal stacking configuration is: A on B, B on C, C on D, D on E, E on F, F on G, G on H, H on I, I on J, and J on the table.

analysis.system_prompt: You are an agent expert at manipulating vowel-labelled blocks in a block-stacking domain. You should not emit PDDL directly. Instead, provide an analysis of your capabilities, the local constraints you observe, which vowel blocks are initially movable (i.e., which are top-of-stack), safe intermediate placements you can perform, and any assumptions you need the orchestrator to resolve. Keep your analysis specific, factual, and grounded in the public information.
analysis.prompt: Your name is vowel_agent. You can only move vowel blocks (A, E, I, O, U). You can only act on top blocks and move one block at a time. Here is the public information about the environment and initial stacks: There are ten blocks G, I, D, F, C, B, H, A, J, E. Initially: G on table, I on table, D on table, F on G, C on I, B on C, H on D, A on F, J on A, E on H. The global goal is: A on B, B on C, C on D, D on E, E on F, F on G, G on H, H on I, I on J, J on table. Provide a clear list of which vowel blocks you can move initially, what moves you can perform without violating your constraints, what intermediate placements you consider valid (e.g., placing on table or on top of specific blocks), and any missing information or ambiguities you need the orchestrator to resolve.

analysis.system_prompt: You are an agent expert at manipulating consonant-labelled blocks in a block-stacking domain. You should not emit PDDL directly. Instead, provide an analysis of your capabilities, the local constraints you observe, which consonant blocks are initially movable, safe intermediate placements you can perform, and any assumptions you need the orchestrator to resolve. Keep your analysis specific, factual, and grounded in the public information.
analysis.prompt: Your name is consonant_agent. You can only move consonant blocks (B, C, D, F, G, H, J and others). You can only act on top blocks and move one block at a time. Here is the public information about the environment and initial stacks: There are ten blocks G, I, D, F, C, B, H, A, J, E. Initially: G on table, I on table, D on table, F on G, C on I, B on C, H on D, A on F, J on A, E on H. The global goal is: A on B, B on C, C on D, D on E, E on F, F on G, G on H, H on I, I on J, J on table. Provide a clear list of which consonant blocks you can move initially, what moves you can perform without violating your constraints, what intermediate placements you consider valid, and any missing information or ambiguities you need the orchestrator to resolve.

pddl.system_prompt: You are an expert in multi-agent PDDL planning for the FastDownwards planner. Using the agents' analyses, produce a complete PDDL domain and a PDDL problem that encodes the block world described and the global stacking goal. You must keep actions of the two agents distinct in the domain (for example, vowel-move and consonant-move actions) and encode the constraint that each agent can only move blocks of their allowed letter types and only top blocks. The PDDL must be compatible with FastDownwards and include types, predicates for on, ontable, clear, holding, and actions for pickup, putdown, stack, unstack as appropriate. Enclose the PDDL domain between <domain> and </domain> tags and the PDDL problem between <problem> and </problem> tags. Produce only the domain and problem text wrapped in those tags.
pddl.prompt: You are the orchestrator. You will receive the two agents' analyses about their move capabilities and constraints. Integrate that information to create a single coherent PDDL domain and problem file that achieves the global goal: A on B, B on C, C on D, D on E, E on F, F on G, G on H, H on I, I on J, J on table. Ensure the domain distinguishes vowel and consonant actions and enforces top-of-stack and single-block move constraints. Target the output for the FastDownwards solver. Output the PDDL domain enclosed in <domain> tags and the PDDL problem enclosed in <problem> tags.
